prompt: Impact of cloud computing on modern IT infrastructure.

criteria.name: Understanding of Topic
criteria.description: Demonstrates clear and accurate understanding of cloud computing and its impact on IT infrastructure.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Displays comprehensive knowledge and insightful connections to the topic.
performance_descriptors.good: Shows clear understanding with minor errors or omissions.
performance_descriptors.average: Basic knowledge with some misunderstandings or generalizations.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Limited grasp of the topic; key ideas missing.
performance_descriptors.poor: Fails to convey understanding of cloud computing or IT infrastructure.

criteria.name: Application to Real-World Context
criteria.description: Effectively relates cloud computing concepts to real-world IT scenarios and infrastructure.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Provides rich, relevant, and realistic examples or experiences.
performance_descriptors.good: Examples are appropriate and mostly relevant.
performance_descriptors.average: Some real-world application, but lacks detail or depth.
performance_descriptors.needs_improvement: Vague or poorly connected real-world references.
performance_descriptors.poor: No meaningful application to real-world IT contexts.

criteria.name: Critical Thinking and Insight
criteria.description: Shows depth of thought and insight in discussing implications, challenges, or future directions.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Demonstrates critical insight, questioning assumptions or exploring complexities.
performance_descriptors.good: Shows some thoughtful analysis beyond basic explanation.
performance_descriptors.average: Some insight, but largely descriptive or surface-level.

criteria.name: Originality and Perspective
criteria.description: Brings a unique point of view or reflection that adds value beyond general knowledge.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Offers a distinct and engaging perspective with original reflections or experiences.
performance_descriptors.good: Demonstrates some personal insight or unique angle.
performance_descriptors.average: Some originality present, but mostly general or derivative.
performance_descriptors.poor: No originality; generic or copied response.

criteria.name: Clarity and Communication
criteria.description: Presents ideas clearly, logically, and in a well-structured manner suitable for an IT audience.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Clear, concise, and well-organized; highly appropriate for audience.
performance_descriptors.good: Generally clear and logical; some lapses in flow or word choice.
performance_descriptors.average: Understood with effort; lacks polish or has minor confusion.
performance_descriptors.poor: Very difficult to understand or follow.

submissions.final_submission: Cloud computing has significantly transformed modern IT infrastructure by enabling resource elasticity, high availability, and cost-effective scalability. Organizations now rely on Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) and Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) models to deploy and manage applications without the burden of physical hardware. Moreover, features like automated backups, disaster recovery, and serverless computing have allowed IT departments to increase operational efficiency while reducing overhead.

By decoupling applications from on-premises infrastructure, cloud computing supports rapid innovation through continuous integration and deployment (CI/CD) pipelines. IT teams can provision environments within minutes, leverage container orchestration with Kubernetes, and ensure compliance via built-in monitoring tools. The agility introduced by cloud-native architectures has made IT infrastructure more resilient, adaptable, and aligned with business objectives.

During the pandemic, I was working as a systems analyst for a mid-sized firm that had to transition to remote work almost overnight. If we hadn't already started moving our infrastructure to AWS the year before, we would've faced serious downtime. The cloud allowed our team to set up virtual desktops, scale VPN access, and ensure secure file sharing without needing to physically access our office servers. It wasn’t just a technical shift — it changed the way our IT team operated and collaborated with other departments.

I’ve been part of a cloud migration project where we moved from legacy on-prem servers to Microsoft Azure. It wasn’t smooth at first — a lot of the legacy apps didn’t integrate well, and some of our team members struggled with the new workflows. But after a few months of training and tweaking our deployment strategy, productivity improved significantly. Maintenance costs dropped, and we no longer had to schedule late-night downtimes to patch servers. It really showed how cloud infrastructure can support both stability and flexibility in IT.

When we decided to adopt cloud infrastructure for our internal tools, we used AI tools to predict usage patterns and plan our auto-scaling policies. But what the AI couldn’t account for was the learning curve our staff would face — many weren’t familiar with cloud-native environments. It took team workshops and mentorship to make the transition successful. The result was worth it, though — cost savings, fewer outages, and faster development cycles. To me, it highlighted that while AI offers data-driven insights, the human side — communication, training, decision-making — is what ensures long-term success.

We used AI-powered performance analyzers during our cloud migration to optimize compute resource allocation across departments. The recommendations were technically sound, but some business units had concerns about access times and data sovereignty. We had to hold several stakeholder sessions to adapt the AI’s suggestions to our real-world constraints. It made me realize that while AI excels in optimization, human input ensures ethical, compliant, and practical outcomes. It’s this hybrid approach that led to a cloud setup that truly worked for everyone.
